subject: Re: Thinking of improving the auto generation of test cases
msgSnippet: ... Generally, if you do in fact have a failing test before righting the code that test is intended to exercise, then it is TDD in some sort. /Good/ TDD though
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Jeffrey Fredrick"
<jeffrey.fredrick@...> wrote:
>
> On 12/28/06, Ilja Preuss <it@...> wrote:
> > Lasse Koskela schrieb:
> >
> > > I'd suggest forgetting TDD in this context. Instead, talk about what
> > > you are doing: automatic test generation. If you take a look at
> > > Agitar's marketing material
> > > (http://www.agitar.com/solutions/business/create_junit_tests.html),
> > > they're not talking about TDD either--because automatic test
> > > generation and TDD are simply two unrelated things.
> >
> > In fact the German marketing material once mentioned TDD, which made
> > them lose a lot of credibility in my eyes...
> >
>
> Which is why they don't say that any more. :)
>
> But for people who don't practice TDD this is a difficult distinction:
> if you have a failing test before you write the code, why isn't that
> enough to be TDD?

Generally, if you do in fact have a failing test before righting the
code that test is intended to exercise, then it is TDD in some sort.
/Good/ TDD though is a bit more than the just fundamental 'test first'
rule - it involves a rapid cycle of 'test first', then code, then
refactor. In other words, as people have indicated earlier: small
steps from which the design emerges.

>
> I *think* what Jimm is talking about doing is generating a test from
> the comment before the implementation is written, so you would have a
> failing test before the body of the code was there. Similarly our
> (Agitar) marketing people had the feeling that if our product would
> let you write a failing test in advance of the code that was TDD,
> right?

It seems to me that what Jimm is doing is actually writing "the code",
then generating a test, then writing "the code" again. Remember - DRY.
In other words, the 'comments' written to generate the test are
"CODE", just not java code.

Think of TDD without the words "test" and "code". The essence of TDD
is that you first write "what should it do?", then write "how it does
it". Generally, the "what should I do" is specified in the "test";
the "how it does it" is specified in the "code [under test]".

>
> The explanation I've used is to distinguish between TDD in the small
> (or test-first) and TDD in the large.
>
> I might find a bug, write a failing test for the bug, and the fix the
> bug. That's would be test-first programming (or TDD in the small).

Yes, that is in fact TDD.

> It's a good thing to do, but the tests aren't driving my design.

Maybe they do, maybe they don't. Probably depends on the scope of the
bug.

>
> Isn't trying to make this distinction clearer what drove people to
> change the name from Test First Development --> TDDevelopement -->
> TDDesign --> BDDesign? Gotta be a FAQ on this somewhere...

I don't know what drives people to keep renaming the same thing over
and over, but I do know it's aggrevating :-)

>
> Jtf
>

>
> http://www.developertesting.com/
>

Cheers...
--MB
